title: Problems of: Rolled back headers and Synchronization failed, dropping peer ...
body:
#### System information

Geth version: 1.6.5 -stable - cf87713d
OS & Version: Linux 16.04.02 LTS - (Virtualized)
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

#### Expected behaviour


I worked on it for a week. I've read many forums about this problem (if it's really a problem), many talk about time synchronization, tried and failed, I even install an NTP, but it did not work ... I've done everything, how to remove Chaindata and Mas remains In the same situation. I need to synchronize this block chain to continue developing my project, but I do not know how.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

My virtual machine has 2Gb of RAM, 160Gb HD and 2 cores processing, Internet 10Mb. As for the network is normal, I use two network cards, one in NAT mode and the other in HostOnly for access via SSH through PUttyn.

I used this command to start the Blocks chain: geth --testnet --syncmode=light --rpc --rpcapi db,eth,net,web3,personal --cache=1024  --rpcport 8545 --rpcaddr 127.0.0.1 --rpccorsdomain "*" --bootnodes "enode://20c9ad97c081d63397d7b685a412227a40e23c8bdc6688c6f37e97cfbc22d2b4d1db1510d8f61e6a8866ad7f0e17c02b14182d37ea7c3c8b9c2683aeb6b733a1@52.169.14.227:30303,enode://6ce05930c72abc632c58e2e4324f7c7ea478cec0ed4fa2528982cf34483094e9cbc9216e7aa349691242576d552a2a56aaeae426c5303ded677ce455ba1acd9d@13.84.180.240:30303"

#### Backtrace

````
[backtrace]
````

Please follow issues #14608, #14626 and #14647 if it helps. If you are sure there is no hardware problem and you are using ssd instead of hdd then my suggestion is use geth in full mode or use parity. I had wasted 20 days on this. Currently geth has some serious bugs but not every body affected every time. I have full faith on the developers that they will come out with a clean build in near future.

I support this point of view, which means, the geth app has currently no deterministic behaviour. I have done 5 different approaches (virtual machines, dedicated machine), all without success, and the comunity generally tells you to restart from scratch (based on opinion, not on knowledge). When reading all the comments, it looks like "slower machines" and small network do not come to sync. They start to sync, but then never reach the last block, and instead loads tons of state entries for a long time. There is no reply I could find as to what this means (state entries and the syncing process), and how long does it take. It only says, it can reach a number between 8 and 10mio. I showed my experience in a comment here:
https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/14571
Looks like you have to have a fast network and QuadCore and +4Gig RAM and SSD, to successfully load/sync ether chaindata. 
Experts to prove me wrong please.
On trust in devs: yes, but on this topic: they usually work with fast machines, and certainly don't feel the issue as such... it would stop them from working. So no, it is not a question of trust. A system which shall move money or virtual values around, being non-deterministic cannot gain much trust...

I've been trying to sync 20 days of history for over 7 days now. I have a decently fast machine too; here are my stats:

Intel Core i5-6500 CPU @ 3.20 GHz
500 GB SSD (400 GB available space)
8 GB DDR5 Ram
GeForce GTX 1050 Ti 4GB

I have a backup of chaindata up to 20 days ago, but I seem entirely unable to sync the last 20 days and even less success syncing the entire chain with geth or geth --fast. It always gets corrupted along the way, and I have no malfunctioning hardware.  If anyone has suggestions about what I can do to sync the chain, please respond.

Please check your network speed. It should be fast and stable (should be 2 mbps at least). The current version of geth is worked as --fast mode by default. So geth and geth --fast is same. Try using geth --full mode. It will take time about 2 to 3 weeks but **more probably** successfully sync.

My network speed is 15 mbps per second on average over ethernet not wireless. During geth sync there are no other computers connected to the network except 2 antminers (they use very little bandwidth). To avoid corruption I can only create regularly timed backups so I don't lose everything when it inevitably crashes. I did eventually get it to sync this way, but there's really no problem in my hardware configuration.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
